sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Chronic lymphoid leukemia, In patients who have received at least 1 prior therapy: 420 mg ORALLY daily at the same time each day
  • Chronic lymphoid leukemia, In patients with 17p chromosome deletion: 420 mg ORALLY daily at the same time each day
  • Mantle cell lymphoma, In previously treated patients: 560 mg ORALLY once daily at the same time each day
  • Waldenstroem macroglobulinemia: 420 mg ORALLY once daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy in pediatric patients not established

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Hepatic impairment, mild (Child-Pugh class A): Reduce dose to 140 mg/day
  • Hepatic impairment, moderate or severe (Child-Pugh class B or C): Avoid use
  • Concomitant moderate CYP3A inhibitor: Reduce the ibrutinib dose to 140 mg/day
  • Concomitant strong CYP3A inhibitor administered for 7 or fewer days: Consider interrupting ibrutinib therapy until the CYP3A inhibitor is no longer necessary; use of a strong CYP3A inhibitor requiring chronic administration is not recommended.
  • Hematologic events (grade 4): Interrupt and resume at the starting dose upon resolution to grade 1 or baseline; if toxicity reoccurs, reinitiate at a dose reduced by 140 mg/day; with a third reoccurrence, reinitiate at a second reduction of 140 mg/day; if toxicities persist or recur following 2 dose reductions, discontinue therapy .
  • Neutropenia with infection or fever (grade 3 or greater): Interrupt and resume at the starting dose upon resolution to grade 1 or baseline; if toxicity reoccurs, reinitiate at a dose reduced by 140 mg/day; with a third reoccurrence, reinitiate at a second reduction of 140 mg/day; if toxicities persist or recur following 2 dose reductions, discontinue therapy.
  • Nonhematologic adverse events (grade 3 or greater): Interrupt and resume at the starting dose upon resolution to grade 1 or baseline; if toxicity reoccurs, reinitiate at a dose reduced by 140 mg/day; with a third reoccurrence, reinitiate at a second reduction of 140 mg/day; if toxicities persist or recur following 2 dose reductions, discontinue therapy.
  • Surgery: Consider interruption of ibrutinib therapy for at least 3 to 7 days prior to and after surgery, depending on the surgery type and bleeding risk.

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Chronic lymphoid leukemia, In patients who have received at least 1 prior therapy
  • Chronic lymphoid leukemia, In patients with 17p chromosome deletion
  • Mantle cell lymphoma, In previously treated patients
  • Waldenstroem macroglobulinemia

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- Atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter have occurred, particularly among patients with acute infection or a history of atrial fibrillation or cardiac risk factors; monitoring recommended; dose adjustment or discontinuation may be required
  • Dermatologic:
  • -- Second primary malignancies, including skin cancer and other carcinomas, have been reported
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Serious, sometimes fatal, bleeding events (ie, hemorrhage, subdural hematoma, gastrointestinal bleeding, hematuria) have occurred, especially with concurrent use of antiplatelets or anticoagulants
  • -- Serious cytopenias (ie, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia) have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Mild impairment requires dose adjustment and monitoring; avoid use in moderate or severe impairment
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Infection, including fatal cases, have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Avoid pregnancy during use; may cause fetal harm
  • Other:
  • -- Consider withholding treatment for at least 3 to 7 days before and after surgery, depending on the risk of bleeding
  • -- Tumor lysis syndrome has been reported; monitoring recommended; take precautions in patients with increased risk
  • -- Patients aged 65 and older at increased risk for serious adverse effects (eg, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, pneumonia, cellulitis, diarrhea, dehydration)
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Avoid concomitant use of strong or moderate CYP3A inhibitors, including grapefruit and Seville oranges; if clinically required, monitoring indicated with possible dose reduction or interruption
  • -- Avoid concomitant use of strong CYP3A inducers (ie, carbamazepine, rifampin, phenytoin, St John's wort)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Peripheral edema (23% to 35%)
  • Dermatologic:Rash (22% to 27%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Increased uric acid level (40%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (15% to 24%), Constipation (15% to 25%), Decrease in appetite (17% to 21%), Diarrhea (37% to 63%), Nausea (21% to 31%), Stomatitis (16% to 21%), Vomiting (14% to 23%)
  • Hematologic:Bleeding (50%), Contusion (11% to 54%), Decreased hemoglobin, All grades (13%% to 44%), Decreased platelet count, All grades (43% to 71%), Neutropenia, All grades (44% to 54%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (11% to 23%), Musculoskeletal pain (27% to 37%), Spasm (14% to 21%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (11% to 21%)
  • Respiratory:Dyspnea (10% to 27%), Sinusitis (11% to 21%), Upper respiratory infection (16% to 48%)
  • Other:Fatigue (28% to 41%), Fever (18% to 25%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Atrial fibrillation, Grade 3 or 4, Atrial flutter, Grade 3 or 4
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal hemorrhage, Grade 3 or 4
  • Hematologic:Bleeding, Grade 3 or higher (Up to 6%), Decreased hemoglobin, Grade 3 or 4 (0% to 9%), Decreased platelet count, Grade 3 or 4 (5% to 17%), Neutropenia, Grade 3 or 4 (19% to 29%), Subdural hematoma
  • Renal:Hematuria, Renal failure
  • Respiratory:Pneumonia (10% to 15%)
  • Other:Infectious disease, Grade 3 or higher (25% to 26%), Secondary malignant neoplastic disease (5% to 14%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ibrutinib is a Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK) inhibitor that interferes with malignant B-cell proliferation and survival (in vivo), as well as cell migration and substrate adhesion (in vitro).

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 1 to 2 hours
  • Effects of food: 2- to 4-fold increase in Cmax; 2-fold increase in AUC

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Liver: extensive
  • PCI-45227: active
  • inhibitor of P-glycoprotein (P-gp) in the gastrointestinal tract due to higher local concentrations following an oral dose; unlikely to be a P-gp inhibitor systemically at therapeutic doses
  • substrate of CYP3A4 (primary) and CYP2D6 (minor)

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: 80% metabolites; 1% unchanged
  • Renal: 20% metabolites; 0% unchanged
  • Renal clearance: less than 10%
  • Total body clearance: 1000 L/hr (fed state); 2000 L/hr (fasted state)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
Swallow capsules whole with water; do not open, break, or chew

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Evidence of disease response or stabilization is indicative of efficacy
  • CBC; monthly during treatment; including differential
  • Bleeding; during therapy
  • Fever or signs of infection, especially in elderly patients
  • Atrial fibrillation; periodically, especially in elderly patients
  • Patients at risk for tumor lysis syndrome

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Counsel patient to report symptoms of an infection or hemorrhage.
  • Tell patient to report symptoms of atrial fibrillation or flutter.
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of tumor lysis syndrome.
  • Side effects may include nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, constipation, upper respiratory tract infection, fatigue, bruising, rash, musculoskeletal pain, and peripheral edema.
  • Tell patient to maintain adequate hydration and to report persistent diarrhea.
  • Counsel patient to report any new skin lesions.
  • Instruct patient to avoid grapefruit products and Seville oranges.
  • Advise patient to take a missed dose as soon as possible on the same day and to resume a normal dosing schedule.
